content.description:
Stand start halfway through

MFer

. The start is the great crimp huecos in the middle of the overhang. Go straight up the rock instead of traveling right, the key is to keep your weight to the right so the rail for the left hand becomes positive. The holds still break a bit, so use caution as you climb the rest of the face up.
content.protection: Three pads, or a spotter and two pads. I cleared the rocks as best I could.
content.location: This boulder, if you parked as far forward in the large lot as you can, is to your left 100 feet. This would be where you have to cross (with care) or go around the fence. This boulder, after a lot of cleaning and breaking holds, has become a gem low in the canyon and offers amazing overhanging problems.

content.description:
RCMF'er adds a couple of hard moves to

MFer

, ... I had to use a really technical heel toe cam to barely manage!
content.protection: You will likely want 3 or 4 pads, or a one talented spotter that can shuffle well (boot scoot boogie level).
content.location: Start on a left hand pocket and right hand underling pocket.

content.description:
This is a long route. It is low and left. The start is big - sit under the rock, don't start on that low thing that seems like "holy sh$t, really?" unless you want to link it somehow (the grade would be much harder). Look up more, get an awesome left hand jug (after crimp broke, opened up the glory). Now find a right hand undercling and crappy right foot, and throw left over for an ankle scraping heel hook. Move right hand to a two finger, tiny pocket to balance as you swing and make that big move up to a decent rail. Throw farther than you think, make room to match, carry your heel hooks, move with the obvious traversing line, slopers, fancy feet, move up through some great holds on the dihedral thing.

youtube.com/watch?v=8cgfC9Dâ€¦
content.protection: I used three pads. One spotter and two pads would do. These rocks are mean and change when it rains. I've cleared out all that I could.
